intro: Rhagodia baccata subsp. dioica, commonly known as the mountain thimbleweed, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in open habitats such as woodlands and grasslands. It has a taproot system and produces small, berry-like fruits that are enclosed in a bract. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
